webTitle: Eurozone crisis as it happened: Greece gets more time as IMF and EU clash

fields.standfirst:
• Athens given until 2016 to hit its fiscal targets
• Lagarde and Juncker argue over Greek targets
• Final decision on Greece's aid tranche delayed until November 20
• Vodafone takes writedown on Italy and Spain
• Euro falls
fields.body:
5.39pm GMT

European markets edge higher despite Greek disputes

European markets have closed and despite the dispute between the IMF and EU over Greece's fate, they have managed to edge higher. An opening bounce on Wall Street as well as vague talk Spain might finally request a bailout seemed to do the trick.

• The FTSE 100 finished up 0.33%

• Germany's Dax edged up 0.01%

• France's Cac closed up 0.56%

• Spain's Ibex jumped 1.66%

• Italy's FTSE MIB finished 1.4% higher

And the Athens stock market closed up 0.37% although the country's banking sector lost 2.8%.

Meanwhile the Dow Jones Industrial Average has come off its best levels, but is still up 0.22%. Chris Beauchamp, market analyst at IG, said:

Despite all its problems and the bleak future that awaits, it seems Greece has managed to find some demand for its short-term debt. An auction today managed to raise €4 billion, more than expected. In further good news, there were suggestions that Germany is looking to throw a bumper payout in Greece’s direction, which would at least buy time.

These two pieces of good news seem to have steadied the ship for now, with markets recovering lost ground, although the day's widespread pessimism has not abated yet. A new problem is the Catalonian referendum, which is scheduled for 25 November. Spain’s situation teeters on a knife-edge, as bond yields show, and while Greece might have bought itself more time that's a resource Spain seems to be running short of. It can't be long before Mariano Rajoy is forced to formally request help.

And on that note it's time to shut up shop for the evening. We'll be back tomorrow to cover the European strikes and all the day's other developments.

Updated at 5.41pm GMT

5.26pm GMT

Greek protests continue ahead of tomorrow's general strike

Over in Greece it’s been another busy day on the industrial action front, reports our correspondent Helena Smith.

While Greek politicians have been number crunching in Brussels, workers in Greece have been either taking to the streets or walking off the job. Earlier today hundreds of striking metal workers employed at shipyards in the port of Pireaus angrily marched through Athens before protesting en masse outside the finance ministry in Syntagma square.

“We want work. We don’t want to be unemployed. Hands of shipyards,” they chanted. “The yards have been completely abandoned by the state. Most of us haven’t been paid for the past seven months,” said Yiannis Stefanopoulos who as head of the Panhellenic Metalworkers Federation (POEM) was leading the protest march. “This is having a tragic effect with entire families literally being torn apart.”

Ahead of tomorrow’s pan-European general strike in protest over austerity measures, civil servants also staged a three-hour work stoppage. “We will stage another one tomorrow along with private sector workers,” said Tania Karayiannis at ADEDY, the union that represents public sector employees. “All over Europe people are being forced by national governments and the EU to suffer the most extreme neoliberal policies under the pretext of solving this crisis,” she said. “All these policies are unfair but today we focused on protesting against lay-offs in the public sector outside the administrative reform ministry.”

Updated at 5.40pm GMT

5.02pm GMT

Cameron and Monti "not in perfect agreement" on EU budget

UK prime minister David Cameron has said he would be writing to EC president Van Rompuy suggesting a "single market council", and also said Britain would support banking union "as long as we can achieve the safeguards we need."

At a press conference in Rome he told Italian prime minister Mario Monti their two countries were both large contributors to the EU and financial control was needed.

Monti had said the two countries were not in perfect agreement on the EU budget.

4.26pm GMT

Cameron and Monti meet

Meanwhile David Cameron is meeting Italian prime minister Mario Monti in Rome:

Updated at 4.32pm GMT

4.24pm GMT

Hollande says Greece deserves aid

French president François Hollande has said Greece deserves Europe's aid, in a press conference taking place at the moment (link here).

He also said France must undertake reforms to bring down public spending.

4.10pm GMT

Schäuble says bumper Greek payout is part of discussion

Germany's finance minister Wolfgang Schäuble has added fuel to the fire of a possible bumper €44bn aid payment to Greece.

According to Reuters snaps, he said paying out three tranches of aid in one go was part of the discussions. But, and here's the but, it needed control mechanisms for it to be paid out.

3.53pm GMT

Greek finance minister calls for bank deposits to be returned to country

Greek finance minister Yannis Stournaras has said that recapitalising the country's banks is not enough to lift their liquidity levels to where they need to be.

Speaking in Brussels he has called for money taken out of Greece to be repatriated. He reckoned around a third of deposits which fled the country have now returned.

He has added:

Updated at 4.31pm GMT

3.43pm GMT

Cost of insuring eurozone debt against default on the rise

It's not just shares and currencies which have reacted badly to the lack of any resolution to the eurozone crisis. The cost of insuring sovereign debt against default for key eurozone countries has jumped sharply this month.

Joe Rundle, head of trading at ETX Capital, said:

The troika holding fire on unlocking the next tranche of funds for Greece has not only pushed the euro below the 1.27 level this week, but credit default swaps for peripheral euro zone countries are on the rise. Spain’s CDS shot up 32% on the month, while Italian CDS are up around 35% for the same period. Worryingly, French CDS are up a staggering 42% on the month while German CDS are up 33%, indicating the pressure is being felt more by the core nations over the peripheral.

Although all mentioned CDS are not at levels reached during the summer and still a considerable way off, this recent rise threatens to undo the rally triggered by the ECB’s OMT backstop announced in September which aims to assist struggling nations who need financial support. As long as the troika squabble over Greece’s next trance of funds, we can expect continued pressure on CDS levels which could reach the highs of the summer of 2012 if no solution to Greece’s future and the US fiscal cliff can be found.

2.08pm GMT

Spanish minister says no proposals to change deficit targets

Spain's economy minister Luis de Guindos has told reporters in Brussels there is no current proposal to renegotiate the country's deficit targets.

He has also reportedly put much of the blame on Greece for Spain's high borrowing costs:

Meanwhile, speaking in London, IMF deputy managing director David Lipton has praised Ireland and Portugal for complying well with their IMF programmes although they still face problems.

Indeed, earlier the Bank of Portugal cut its forecast for GDP in 2013 from no growth to a fall of 1.6%. It added that the projection was highly uncertain. It kept its forecast of a 3% fall in GDP for the current year, in line with the government's estimate. However it has become more pessimistic about next year than the government, which expects a 1% contraction.

2.00pm GMT

German vote on Greece bailout reportedly after Eurogroup meeting

There are suggestions that Germany's vote on the Greek bailout will now not happen before the Eurogroup meeting next week, which of course will add another delay to the already tortuous process.

Updated at 2.04pm GMT

12.32pm GMT

Greek government optimistic after Eurogroup meeting

Over in Greece, the government appears to be expressing optimism over the outcome of the Eurogroup meeting ahead of a renewed push in Brussels by prime minister Antonis Samaras. Our correspondent Helena Smith writes:

With the Greek prime minister Antonis Samaras poised to hold talks with European Commission president Jose Manuel Barroso in Brussels, officials in Athens are in upbeat mood. Aides say the conservative leader will impress upon Barroso for rescue funds to be released as soon as possible saying “with the budget vote Greece has done its bit, now it is up to Europe to do the same.”

The Greek finance minister Yiannis Stournaras, who is in Brussels, says despite disagreement between the EU and IMF over how to resolve Greece’s debt sustainability, disbursement of the long-delayed €31.5bn aid package is now a “done deal.” The technocrat said he believed the entire amount would be “deposited in an account at the Bank of Greece by the end of November or early December” once individual member state parliaments had voted on the package.

After months of nail-biting negotiations over biting austerity measures and other structural reforms demanded by the country’s “troika” of creditors at the EU, ECB and IMF, officials described the mood between Athens and its lenders “as discernibly different. We are very pleased with the troika report which really is a landmark in raising our country’s credibility abroad,” said one insider.

Sournaras, like Samaras, has cautioned however that the hard work begins now with implementation of the accord. “This is a government that will not know Sundays or holidays,” said Samaras.

Updated at 2.03pm GMT

12.22pm GMT

The focus is on Greece at the moment but that shouldn't conceal the fact that the problems are much more widespread.

That's the view of Steen Jakobsen, chief economist at Saxo, who said:

I remain of the opinion that Greece will “break from the euro” – but in an orderly fashion, meaning with consent of EU and with its support. Greece is no longer the real issue in Europe – where Spain is now where Greece was two-three years ago - a negative growth spiral with no voter support. The Catalonian election on 23 November could escalate Spain’s issues and hence also the Greek situation.

So far in this crisis we have dealt with countries one-by-one. First Greece and Ireland, then Portugal then Spain/Italy, then back to Greece, then Spain, but now… Spain is on the edge, Greece is hanging onto the edge and Europe outlook for growth and political resolve is further away than before.

Greece could become the “sacrifice” needed to get European reforms back on track.

12.01pm GMT

Report: Germany considering bumper aid payout for Greece.....

The euro just jumped by half a cent against the US dollar, erasing this morning's losses, on the back of a (rather curious) report that the German government is considering a plan to give Greece a €44bn aid payment.

Bild, the German tabloid, is claiming that Berlin wants to bundle three aid tranches (including the long-delayed €31.5bn payment) into a single one.

Asked about it, a German government spokeswoman said that 'no final decision' has yet been taken about Greece's aid. Which isn't exactly a denial.

Financial experts aren't immediately sure what to make of the report, but one theory is that the figure includes the 'profits' the European Central Bank has made by buying Greek debt at distressed levels since the crisis began:

Developing.... (and on that note, I have to dash to a meeting so my colleague Nick Fletcher has the controls...). Cheers, GW

Updated at 12.06pm GMT

11.50am GMT

Juncker pours oil on troubled waters

Some quotes from Jean-Claude Juncker just hit the wires.

The Eurogroup chair has attempted to calm the situation after last night's public spat with Christine Lagarde, insisting that there is 'no real dispute' between Europe and the International Monetary Fund.

Juncker added that he was 'confident' that the IMF would remain as a member of the Greek aid programme.

An attempt to calm fears that policymakers are at each other's throats? If so, more reassurance may be needed....

11.33am GMT

Photos from Brussels

EU finance ministers have gathered in Brussels for today's Ecofin meeting, and here are a couple of snaps:

The meeting is expected to focus on methods to boost the slumping economy, and the sticky issue of the EU budget.

And speaking of Schäuble, our Ian Traynor points out that the German finance minister could soon be sharing a job with France's Pierre Moscovici (with whom he sat side-by-side physically and metaphorically this morning)

Schäuble and Moscovici are being touted for a jobshare in the new year - taking turns to chair the Eurogroup of finance ministers if and when Jean-Claude Juncker of Luxembourg steps down.

Both men nimbly sidestepped the question from the French and German media (no questions were granted to non-French, non-German media), and a few months back they also announced the creation of a high-level joint Franco-German working group on economic policy and fortnightly sessions of the two ministers.

Nothing much seems to have come of that, though.

Updated at 11.38am GMT

11.05am GMT

Germany denies Greece will get more funds

Back to Brussels, where German officials are – perhaps for domestic political reasons – denying that the Greek bailout terms are being extended by two years to 2016.

Ian Traynor reports:

“You’re extending the fiscal targets for Greece, you’re not extending the programme, €32bn is not being looked at,” insisted a German finance ministry official. “The programme ends in 2014.”

That €32bn figure has come from the Troika's draft report into Greece, and is its rough estimate of the cost of giving Greece until 2016 to hit its debt reduction targets. So.... that 'open issue' will be discussed by the Eurogroup next week (at the 20 November meeting agreed last night)

On debt sustainability, the official confirmed the dispute which flared into the open on Monday evening, with Christine Lagarde, the IMF chief, and Jean-Claude Juncker, chair of the eurogroup, publicly contradicting one another. 

“You need agreement in the troika and there isn’t any,” said the official.

Or as the FT's Alan Beattie puts it:

It’s not as if the troika of eurozone rescue lenders never falls out, but usually it takes a not-in-front-of-the-children attitude to airing its rows.

More here.

Updated at 11.25am GMT

10.42am GMT

Greece raises €4bn towards avoiding debt default

Just in: Greece has announced that is has raised just over €4bn through its sale of short-term debt.

That leaves it around €1bn short of the €5bn bond which matures at the end of the week.

However, I think the auction is arguably a success -- Greece can raise more money through "non-competitive bids" (ie, selling more bonds at the prices set in today's sale).

Originally Athens had aimed to raise €3.2bn in today's sale of short-term debt. So experts aren't panicking:

Updated at 11.16am GMT

10.29am GMT

Germany and France in show of unity

Wolfgang Schäuble, Germany's finance minister, has emphatically denied that France's economy is in serious trouble, at a press conference with French counterpart Pierre Moscovici in Brussels this morning.

Our Europe editor Ian Traynor was there, and reports:

Amid mounting worries in Berlin that the real elephant in the eurozone room is the unreformed France of François Hollande, both countries’ finance ministers have just attempted a show of unity in the basement of the European Council building in Brussels.

Asked by French TV whether France was now the “sick man of Europe”, Wolfgang Schäuble quickly and emphatically declared: “No, and you must not waste a second in answering that.”

The air was thick with pledges from both Schäuble and Moscovici that Paris and Berlin stand “side by side”, sharing a “common vision” and a “common mission” for Europe.

But the unusual joint appearance before the press following last night’s failure to deliver on Greece might prove counter-productive, suggesting that both men had to perform together to try to dispel the frictions between both sides of the Rhine.

The impression from the joint appearance was that both men rather protest too much that everything is dandy in the Franco-German relationship.

On Greece, the now public differences between the Europeans and the IMF on Greek debt sustainability, and how to fill a two-year funding gap in the bailout put at more than €32bn euros, Schäuble said that the IMF’s 2020 target for Greek debt sustainability was “perhaps too ambitious”. He pooh-poohed all notions of writing down Greece’s debt to its official lenders, effectively conceding that he would not be able to get such a move through the Bundestag in Berlin.

10.12am GMT

Watch last night's press conference

You can watch last night's Eurogroup press conference in the video clip above (although you may find that it 'hangs' if you attempt to scroll forwards and backwards)

Updated at 10.14am GMT

10.10am GMT

ZEW index falls

Economic sentiment in Germany has dropped this month, showing that Europe's biggest economy continues to feel the chill from the euro crisis.

The ZEW survey came in at -15.7, worse than October's -11.5, showing that German economists are more alarmed about Germany's economy.

ZEW blamed "recessionary developments" in the eurozone, which are expected to curtail German economic growth in the next six months.

Economists surveyed were their most pessimistic about the current situation since the summer of 2010.

The news knocked the euro to a new two-month low against the US of $1.26615....

...even though some City analysts question whether the ZEW survey is a particularly helpful measure....

9.36am GMT

UK inflation jumps to 2.7%

UK inflation jumped sharply last month as food, transport and university fees drove up the cost of living.

The Consumer Prices Index rose to 2.7% for October, up from 2.2% in September. That's a much bigger rise than economists had expected, and dampens hopes that UK inflation was finally dropping back to the Bank of England's target of 2%.

City experts are not impressed!

Updated at 9.39am GMT

9.21am GMT

What the analysts say today

City experts are pretty gloomy about the crisis this morning – here's a selection of the latest comments:

Marc Ostwald of Monument Securities:

As we have argued for a very long time, the Greek debt situation will always be unsustainable until its existing pile of debt is written down or off to below 80% of GDP, and this will have primarily to involve public sector holdings.

There are no other solutions ... other than outright default.

Elisabeth Afseth of Evolution Securities

Perhaps European finance ministers may not ever agree not to release the funds, just keeping on not agreeing to release them, there is something a bit ‘Yes, Minister’ about it all....

Officials insisted Greece will be able to raise t-bills to cover redemptions due at the end of this week and thus avoiding another default, it can’t go on forever though, regardless of how much European politicians enjoy making up new ‘Yes, Minister’ episodes.

Gary Jenkins of Swordfish Research

Ms Lagarde and Mr Juncker openly disagreed about the timetable to reduce Greece’s debt / GDP to 120%. The former wants that target achieved by 2020, as initially agreed, whilst the latter would like to extend it to 2022, which sounds a bit like a conversation which might have been had at the Mad Tea Party from Alice in Wonderland.

Unless Greece enjoys an economic miracle or its creditors are prepared to incur losses then it doesn’t really matter if you say 2020, 2022 or 2025, the most likely outcome is that Greece won’t get anywhere near that target. Ms Lagarde would appear to be in favour of an Official Sector Involvement program as she said that Greece needs a “real fix, not a quick fix.”

Lee McDarby of Investec Corporate Treasury:

Yesterday’s Eurogroup meeting has done little to buoy market sentiment towards the shared currency.

Michael Hewson of CMC Markets

The issue of the €5bn Greece Friday loan repayment to the ECB was brushed aside last night, with Olli Rehn saying that he remained sure that Greek banks had enough available collateral to cover today’s Greece t-bill auction.

Given that the success of this auction could dictate whether or not the ECB has to adjust its collateral rules Greek officials will be hoping that the auction is fully covered, and that they can then make the relevant payment on Friday.

Updated at 9.25am GMT

8.49am GMT

The agenda

A quick reminder of what's coming up today

• Ecofin meeting in Brussels: all day

• UK inflation data for October: 9.30am GMT

• German ZEW Survey of economic sentiment: 10am GMT / 11am CET

• Greek €5bn bond sale: morning

• Charles Dallara, head of the Institute of International Finance, visits Greece: all day

• David Cameron visiting Mario Monti: this afternoon

8.41am GMT

Sony Kapoor of the Redefine thinktank has given a cautious welcome to the eurogroup's decision to extend Greece's fiscal programme to 2016

8.32am GMT

Stock markets fall

Europe's failure to make more progress last night has hit stock markets this morning, with the major indices dropping in early trading.

FTSE 100: down 43 points at 5723, -0.75%

German DAX: down 44 points at 7124. -0.6%

French CAC: down 18 points at 3393, - 0.5%

Spanish IBEX: down 64 points at 7503, - 0.83%

Italian FTSE MIB: down 126 points at 14996, -0.8%

Most Asian markets lost ground overnight, with the Hong Kong Hang Seng dropping more than 1%.

Mike McCudden, head of derivatives at stockbroker Interactive Investor, said traders remained alarmed by the Greek situation:

Euro zone ministers failed to agree last night on the next loan tranche for Greece, pushing it even closer to a default.

This delay shouldn't necessarily surprise investors as they await the Troika's report, but pushing them this close to the edge will leave many spooked.

8.20am GMT

Heads-up: the finance ministers of Germany and France are due to give a press conference shortly in Brussels, before the main Ecofin meeting (involving ministers from all 27 EU nations) gets under way.

Updated at 10.26am GMT

8.10am GMT

Vodafone hit by eurozone austerity

The eurozone crisis has hit mobile phone giant Vodafone hard.

The company reported this morning that it is taking a £5.9bn impairment charge on its Spanish and Italian operations. It blamed "challenging market conditions" and "macroeconomic pressures" – with both countries deep in recession.

Vodafone's financial results appear to show the impact of austerity in the eurozone periphery – service revenues across southern Europe are down by 9.8% in the six months to the end of September.

The company said it was suffering from "margin erosion" in Italy, Greece and Portugal – suggesting that people are simply giving up their handsets.

The news has disappointed the City:

Updated at 10.25am GMT

8.04am GMT

Here's how last night's Eurogroup meeting, and the row between Lagarde and Juncker, is being covered this morning:

Financial Times: EU-IMF feud erupts over Greek debt (£)

Eurozone finance ministers last night postponed agreement on Greece’s long-delayed €31.3bn aid payment for yet another week as divisions between the International Monetary Fund and EU creditors over how fast Athens must reduce its burgeoning debt levels burst into the open.

Christine Lagarde, the IMF chief, and Jean-Claude Juncker, chair of the eurogroup of finance ministers, publicly sparred over whether Greece must reduce its debt levels to 120 per cent of economic output by 2020, long viewed the target to get Athens back to a sustainable debt level.

Daily Telegraph: IMF chief and EU clash over Greek debt

A conflict between the International Monetary Fund and European Union erupted into the open on Monday night after Christine Lagarde publicly clashed with eurozone finance ministers over a critical target for reducing Greek debt levels.

Reuters: Greece wins more time but no immediate aid

Greece's international lenders agreed on Monday to give the country two more years to make the cuts demanded of it but the euro zone and IMF clashed over a longer-term target date to shrink the country's debt pile.

Euro zone finance ministers gathered in Brussels did not disburse more aid to the debt-ridden country and by granting a request from Athens for more time, face an extra funding bill of around 33 billion euros (26.4 billion pounds), according to a document prepared for the meeting.

Wall Street Journal: Lenders at Odds Over Greek Debt

Differences among Greece's official lenders about how to reduce the country's debt to manageable levels spilled into the open late Monday, as the head of the International Monetary Fund emphasized she opposed euro-zone efforts to avoid making significant debt concessions to Greece.

The public show of disagreement after a meeting of euro-zone finance ministers meeting here—following months of behind-the-scenes bickering over debt targets—indicated that lenders have a lot of work to do to settle on how to release a long-delayed €31.5 billion ($40 billion) aid payment.

7.47am GMT

Euro hits two-month low

The Eurogroup's failure to take a decision on Greece's aid payment last night has knocked the euro, which hit a new two-month low of $1.2671 against the US dollar in early trading.

7.38am GMT

Greece gets two more years as IMF and Eurogroup clash in public

Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of the eurozone financial crisis, and other key events around the global economy,

Greece has been granted two more years to hit its financial targets. The decision was made late last night in Brussels, at the meeting of eurozone finance ministers.

However the question of whether to hand over its next bailout tranche (worth €31.5bn) has not been taken, with the Eurogroup delaying the decision by another week until 20 November.

That indicates that eurozone officials and the International Monetary Fund remain divided over how to handle Greece (as we covered in yesterday's blog). In particular, how to close the funding gap of around €32bn created by giving Athens two years grace.

The news came at a late-night press conference, at which IMF MD Christine Lagarde and Eurogroup president Jean-Claude Juncker had a dramatic public spat.

The brinkmanship between the IMF and the EU burst into open warfare, after Juncker declared that the deadline for Greece to bring its national debt down to 120% of GDP had been moved by two years, to 2022.

Lagarde denied that this was the case, prompting Juncker to reiterate it and tell reporters that:

I’m not joking.

Cue head-shaking and eye-rolling from Lagarde, who hit back, saying:

In our view, the appropriate timetable is 120 per cent by 2020...We clearly have different views.

We've known for weeks that the IMF and the EU were split over how, and how quickly, to bring Greece's debt into line "burst into the open".

But members of the press pack were still stunned to see the argument vented in public:

So what can we look forward to today? Negotiations will continue in Brussels, where all 27 finance ministers from the EU are meeting. We'll be tracking all the action from there, and reaction to last night's deal.

We also have UK inflation data released this morning, a Greek debt auction (crucial if it is to repay the €5bn loan that matures later this week), and the visit of David Cameron to Rome to meet Mario Monti. Should be lively....

Updated at 10.23am GMT

Most of us haven’t been paid for the past seven months,” said Yiannis Stefanopoulos who as head of the Panhellenic Metalworkers Federation (POEM) was leading the protest march. “This is having a tragic effect with entire families literally being torn apart.” Ahead of tomorrow’s pan-European general strike in protest over austerity measures, civil servants also staged a three-hour work stoppage. “We will stage another one tomorrow along with private sector workers,” said Tania Karayiannis at ADEDY, the union that represents public sector employees. “All over Europe people are being forced by national governments and the EU to suffer the most extreme neoliberal policies under the pretext of solving this crisis,” she said. “All these policies are unfair but today we focused on protesting against lay-offs in the public sector outside the administrative reform ministry.” UK prime minister David Cameron has said he would be writing to EC president Van Rompuy suggesting a "single market council", and also said Britain would support banking union "as long as we can achieve the safeguards we need." At a press conference in Rome he told Italian prime minister Mario Monti their two countries were both large contributors to the EU and financial control was needed. Monti had said the two countries were not in perfect agreement on the EU budget. Meanwhile David Cameron is meeting Italian prime minister Mario Monti in Rome: French president François Hollande has said Greece deserves Europe's aid, in a press conference taking place at the moment (link here). He also said France must undertake reforms to bring down public spending. Germany's finance minister Wolfgang Schäuble has added fuel to the fire of a possible bumper €44bn aid payment to Greece. According to Reuters snaps, he said paying out three tranches of aid in one go was part of the discussions. But, and here's the but, it needed control mechanisms for it to be paid out. Greek finance minister Yannis Stournaras has said that recapitalising the country's banks is not enough to lift their liquidity levels to where they need to be. Speaking in Brussels he has called for money taken out of Greece to be repatriated. He reckoned around a third of deposits which fled the country have now returned. He has added: It's not just shares and currencies which have reacted badly to the lack of any resolution to the eurozone crisis. The cost of insuring sovereign debt against default for key eurozone countries has jumped sharply this month. Joe Rundle, head of trading at ETX Capital, said: The troika holding fire on unlocking the next tranche of funds for Greece has not only pushed the euro below the 1.27 level this week, but credit default swaps for peripheral euro zone countries are on the rise. Spain’s CDS shot up 32% on the month, while Italian CDS are up around 35% for the same period. Worryingly, French CDS are up a staggering 42% on the month while German CDS are up 33%, indicating the pressure is being felt more by the core nations over the peripheral. Although all mentioned CDS are not at levels reached during the summer and still a considerable way off, this recent rise threatens to undo the rally triggered by the ECB’s OMT backstop announced in September which aims to assist struggling nations who need financial support. As long as the troika squabble over Greece’s next trance of funds, we can expect continued pressure on CDS levels which could reach the highs of the summer of 2012 if no solution to Greece’s future and the US fiscal cliff can be found. Spain's economy minister Luis de Guindos has told reporters in Brussels there is no current proposal to renegotiate the country's deficit targets. He has also reportedly put much of the blame on Greece for Spain's high borrowing costs: Meanwhile, speaking in London, IMF deputy managing director David Lipton has praised Ireland and Portugal for complying well with their IMF programmes although they still face problems. Indeed, earlier the Bank of Portugal cut its forecast for GDP in 2013 from no growth to a fall of 1.6%. It added that the projection was highly uncertain. It kept its forecast of a 3% fall in GDP for the current year, in line with the government's estimate. However it has become more pessimistic about next year than the government, which expects a 1% contraction. There are suggestions that Germany's vote on the Greek bailout will now not happen before the Eurogroup meeting next week, which of course will add another delay to the already tortuous process. Over in Greece, the government appears to be expressing optimism over the outcome of the Eurogroup meeting ahead of a renewed push in Brussels by prime minister Antonis Samaras. Our correspondent Helena Smith writes: With the Greek prime minister Antonis Samaras poised to hold talks with European Commission president Jose Manuel Barroso in Brussels, officials in Athens are in upbeat mood. Aides say the conservative leader will impress upon Barroso for rescue funds to be released as soon as possible saying “with the budget vote Greece has done its bit, now it is up to Europe to do the same.” The Greek finance minister Yiannis Stournaras, who is in Brussels, says despite disagreement between the EU and IMF over how to resolve Greece’s debt sustainability, disbursement of the long-delayed €31.5bn aid package is now a “done deal.” The technocrat said he believed the entire amount would be “deposited in an account at the Bank of Greece by the end of November or early December” once individual member state parliaments had voted on the package. After months of nail-biting negotiations over biting austerity measures and other structural reforms demanded by the country’s “troika” of creditors at the EU, ECB and IMF, officials described the mood between Athens and its lenders “as discernibly different. We are very pleased with the troika report which really is a landmark in raising our country’s credibility abroad,” said one insider. Sournaras, like Samaras, has cautioned however that the hard work begins now with implementation of the accord. “This is a government that will not know Sundays or holidays,” said Samaras. The focus is on Greece at the moment but that shouldn't conceal the fact that the problems are much more widespread. That's the view of Steen Jakobsen, chief economist at Saxo, who said: I remain of the opinion that Greece will “break from the euro” – but in an orderly fashion, meaning with consent of EU and with its support. Greece is no longer the real issue in Europe – where Spain is now where Greece was two-three years ago - a negative growth spiral with no voter support. The Catalonian election on 23 November could escalate Spain’s issues and hence also the Greek situation. So far in this crisis we have dealt with countries one-by-one. First Greece and Ireland, then Portugal then Spain/Italy, then back to Greece, then Spain, but now… Spain is on the edge, Greece is hanging onto the edge and Europe outlook for growth and political resolve is further away than before. Greece could become the “sacrifice” needed to get European reforms back on track. The euro just jumped by half a cent against the US dollar, erasing this morning's losses, on the back of a (rather curious) report that the German government is considering a plan to give Greece a €44bn aid payment. Bild, the German tabloid, is claiming that Berlin wants to bundle three aid tranches (including the long-delayed €31.5bn payment) into a single one. Asked about it, a German government spokeswoman said that 'no final decision' has yet been taken about Greece's aid. Which isn't exactly a denial. Financial experts aren't immediately sure what to make of the report, but one theory is that the figure includes the 'profits' the European Central Bank has made by buying Greek debt at distressed levels since the crisis began: Developing.... (and on that note, I have to dash to a meeting so my colleague Nick Fletcher has the controls...). Cheers, GW Some quotes from Jean-Claude Juncker just hit the wires. The Eurogroup chair has attempted to calm the situation after last night's public spat with Christine Lagarde, insisting that there is 'no real dispute' between Europe and the International Monetary Fund. Juncker added that he was 'confident' that the IMF would remain as a member of the Greek aid programme. An attempt to calm fears that policymakers are at each other's throats? If so, more reassurance may be needed.... EU finance ministers have gathered in Brussels for today's Ecofin meeting, and here are a couple of snaps: The meeting is expected to focus on methods to boost the slumping economy, and the sticky issue of the EU budget. And speaking of Schäuble, our Ian Traynor points out that the German finance minister could soon be sharing a job with France's Pierre Moscovici (with whom he sat side-by-side physically and metaphorically this morning) Schäuble and Moscovici are being touted for a jobshare in the new year - taking turns to chair the Eurogroup of finance ministers if and when Jean-Claude Juncker of Luxembourg steps down. Both men nimbly sidestepped the question from the French and German media (no questions were granted to non-French, non-German media), and a few months back they also announced the creation of a high-level joint Franco-German working group on economic policy and fortnightly sessions of the two ministers. Nothing much seems to have come of that, though. Back to Brussels, where German officials are – perhaps for domestic political reasons – denying that the Greek bailout terms are being extended by two years to 2016. Ian Traynor reports: “You’re extending the fiscal targets for Greece, you’re not extending the programme, €32bn is not being looked at,” insisted a German finance ministry official. “The programme ends in 2014.” That €32bn figure has come from the Troika's draft report into Greece, and is its rough estimate of the cost of giving Greece until 2016 to hit its debt reduction targets. So.... that 'open issue' will be discussed by the Eurogroup next week (at the 20 November meeting agreed last night) On debt sustainability, the official confirmed the dispute which flared into the open on Monday evening, with Christine Lagarde, the IMF chief, and Jean-Claude Juncker, chair of the eurogroup, publicly contradicting one another.  “You need agreement in the troika and there isn’t any,” said the official. Or as the FT's Alan Beattie puts it: It’s not as if the troika of eurozone rescue lenders never falls out, but usually it takes a not-in-front-of-the-children attitude to airing its rows. More here. Just in: Greece has announced that is has raised just over €4bn through its sale of short-term debt. That leaves it around €1bn short of the €5bn bond which matures at the end of the week. However, I think the auction is arguably a success -- Greece can raise more money through "non-competitive bids" (ie, selling more bonds at the prices set in today's sale). Originally Athens had aimed to raise €3.2bn in today's sale of short-term debt. So experts aren't panicking: Wolfgang Schäuble, Germany's finance minister, has emphatically denied that France's economy is in serious trouble, at a press conference with French counterpart Pierre Moscovici in Brussels this morning. Our Europe editor Ian Traynor was there, and reports: Amid mounting worries in Berlin that the real elephant in the eurozone room is the unreformed France of François Hollande, both countries’ finance ministers have just attempted a show of unity in the basement of the European Council building in Brussels. Asked by French TV whether France was now the “sick man of Europe”, Wolfgang Schäuble quickly and emphatically declared: “No, and you must not waste a second in answering that.” The air was thick with pledges from both Schäuble and Moscovici that Paris and Berlin stand “side by side”, sharing a “common vision” and a “common mission” for Europe. But the unusual joint appearance before the press following last night’s failure to deliver on Greece might prove counter-productive, suggesting that both men had to perform together to try to dispel the frictions between both sides of the Rhine. The impression from the joint appearance was that both men rather protest too much that everything is dandy in the Franco-German relationship. On Greece, the now public differences between the Europeans and the IMF on Greek debt sustainability, and how to fill a two-year funding gap in the bailout put at more than €32bn euros, Schäuble said that the IMF’s 2020 target for Greek debt sustainability was “perhaps too ambitious”. He pooh-poohed all notions of writing down Greece’s debt to its official lenders, effectively conceding that he would not be able to get such a move through the Bundestag in Berlin. You can watch last night's Eurogroup press conference in the video clip above (although you may find that it 'hangs' if you attempt to scroll forwards and backwards) Economic sentiment in Germany has dropped this month, showing that Europe's biggest economy continues to feel the chill from the euro crisis. The ZEW survey came in at -15.7, worse than October's -11.5, showing that German economists are more alarmed about Germany's economy. ZEW blamed "recessionary developments" in the eurozone, which are expected to curtail German economic growth in the next six months. Economists surveyed were their most pessimistic about the current situation since the summer of 2010. The news knocked the euro to a new two-month low against the US of $1.26615.... ...even though some City analysts question whether the ZEW survey is a particularly helpful measure.... UK inflation jumped sharply last month as food, transport and university fees drove up the cost of living. The Consumer Prices Index rose to 2.7% for October, up from 2.2% in September. That's a much bigger rise than economists had expected, and dampens hopes that UK inflation was finally dropping back to the Bank of England's target of 2%. City experts are not impressed! City experts are pretty gloomy about the crisis this morning – here's a selection of the latest comments: Marc Ostwald of Monument Securities: As we have argued for a very long time, the Greek debt situation will always be unsustainable until its existing pile of debt is written down or off to below 80% of GDP, and this will have primarily to involve public sector holdings. There are no other solutions ... other than outright default. Elisabeth Afseth of Evolution Securities Perhaps European finance ministers may not ever agree not to release the funds, just keeping on not agreeing to release them, there is something a bit ‘Yes, Minister’ about it all.... Officials insisted Greece will be able to raise t-bills to cover redemptions due at the end of this week and thus avoiding another default, it can’t go on forever though, regardless of how much European politicians enjoy making up new ‘Yes, Minister’ episodes. Gary Jenkins of Swordfish Research Ms Lagarde and Mr Juncker openly disagreed about the timetable to reduce Greece’s debt / GDP to 120%. The former wants that target achieved by 2020, as initially agreed, whilst the latter would like to extend it to 2022, which sounds a bit like a conversation which might have been had at the Mad Tea Party from Alice in Wonderland. Unless Greece enjoys an economic miracle or its creditors are prepared to incur losses then it doesn’t really matter if you say 2020, 2022 or 2025, the most likely outcome is that Greece won’t get anywhere near that target. Ms Lagarde would appear to be in favour of an Official Sector Involvement program as she said that Greece needs a “real fix, not a quick fix.” Lee McDarby of Investec Corporate Treasury: Yesterday’s Eurogroup meeting has done little to buoy market sentiment towards the shared currency. Michael Hewson of CMC Markets The issue of the €5bn Greece Friday loan repayment to the ECB was brushed aside last night, with Olli Rehn saying that he remained sure that Greek banks had enough available collateral to cover today’s Greece t-bill auction. Given that the success of this auction could dictate whether or not the ECB has to adjust its collateral rules Greek officials will be hoping that the auction is fully covered, and that they can then make the relevant payment on Friday. A quick reminder of what's coming up today • Ecofin meeting in Brussels: all day • UK inflation data for October: 9.30am GMT • German ZEW Survey of economic sentiment: 10am GMT / 11am CET • Greek €5bn bond sale: morning • Charles Dallara, head of the Institute of International Finance, visits Greece: all day • David Cameron visiting Mario Monti: this afternoon Sony Kapoor of the Redefine thinktank has given a cautious welcome to the eurogroup's decision to extend Greece's fiscal programme to 2016 Europe's failure to make more progress last night has hit stock markets this morning, with the major indices dropping in early trading. FTSE 100: down 43 points at 5723, -0.75% German DAX: down 44 points at 7124. -0.6% French CAC: down 18 points at 3393, - 0.5% Spanish IBEX: down 64 points at 7503, - 0.83% Italian FTSE MIB: down 126 points at 14996, -0.8% Most Asian markets lost ground overnight, with the Hong Kong Hang Seng dropping more than 1%. Mike McCudden, head of derivatives at stockbroker Interactive Investor, said traders remained alarmed by the Greek situation: Euro zone ministers failed to agree last night on the next loan tranche for Greece, pushing it even closer to a default. This delay shouldn't necessarily surprise investors as they await the Troika's report, but pushing them this close to the edge will leave many spooked. Heads-up: the finance ministers of Germany and France are due to give a press conference shortly in Brussels, before the main Ecofin meeting (involving ministers from all 27 EU nations) gets under way. The eurozone crisis has hit mobile phone giant Vodafone hard. The company reported this morning that it is taking a £5.9bn impairment charge on its Spanish and Italian operations. It blamed "challenging market conditions" and "macroeconomic pressures" – with both countries deep in recession. Vodafone's financial results appear to show the impact of austerity in the eurozone periphery – service revenues across southern Europe are down by 9.8% in the six months to the end of September. The company said it was suffering from "margin erosion" in Italy, Greece and Portugal – suggesting that people are simply giving up their handsets. The news has disappointed the City: Here's how last night's Eurogroup meeting, and the row between Lagarde and Juncker, is being covered this morning: Financial Times: EU-IMF feud erupts over Greek debt (£) Eurozone finance ministers last night postponed agreement on Greece’s long-delayed €31.3bn aid payment for yet another week as divisions between the International Monetary Fund and EU creditors over how fast Athens must reduce its burgeoning debt levels burst into the open. Christine Lagarde, the IMF chief, and Jean-Claude Juncker, chair of the eurogroup of finance ministers, publicly sparred over whether Greece must reduce its debt levels to 120 per cent of economic output by 2020, long viewed the target to get Athens back to a sustainable debt level. Daily Telegraph: IMF chief and EU clash over Greek debt A conflict between the International Monetary Fund and European Union erupted into the open on Monday night after Christine Lagarde publicly clashed with eurozone finance ministers over a critical target for reducing Greek debt levels. Reuters: Greece wins more time but no immediate aid Greece's international lenders agreed on Monday to give the country two more years to make the cuts demanded of it but the euro zone and IMF clashed over a longer-term target date to shrink the country's debt pile. Euro zone finance ministers gathered in Brussels did not disburse more aid to the debt-ridden country and by granting a request from Athens for more time, face an extra funding bill of around 33 billion euros (26.4 billion pounds), according to a document prepared for the meeting. Wall Street Journal: Lenders at Odds Over Greek Debt Differences among Greece's official lenders about how to reduce the country's debt to manageable levels spilled into the open late Monday, as the head of the International Monetary Fund emphasized she opposed euro-zone efforts to avoid making significant debt concessions to Greece. The public show of disagreement after a meeting of euro-zone finance ministers meeting here—following months of behind-the-scenes bickering over debt targets—indicated that lenders have a lot of work to do to settle on how to release a long-delayed €31.5 billion ($40 billion) aid payment. The Eurogroup's failure to take a decision on Greece's aid payment last night has knocked the euro, which hit a new two-month low of $1.2671 against the US dollar in early trading. Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of the eurozone financial crisis, and other key events around the global economy, Greece has been granted two more years to hit its financial targets. The decision was made late last night in Brussels, at the meeting of eurozone finance ministers. However the question of whether to hand over its next bailout tranche (worth €31.5bn) has not been taken, with the Eurogroup delaying the decision by another week until 20 November. That indicates that eurozone officials and the International Monetary Fund remain divided over how to handle Greece (as we covered in yesterday's blog). In particular, how to close the funding gap of around €32bn created by giving Athens two years grace. The news came at a late-night press conference, at which IMF MD Christine Lagarde and Eurogroup president Jean-Claude Juncker had a dramatic public spat. The brinkmanship between the IMF and the EU burst into open warfare, after Juncker declared that the deadline for Greece to bring its national debt down to 120% of GDP had been moved by two years, to 2022. Lagarde denied that this was the case, prompting Juncker to reiterate it and tell reporters that: I’m not joking. Cue head-shaking and eye-rolling from Lagarde, who hit back, saying: In our view, the appropriate timetable is 120 per cent by 2020...We clearly have different views. We've known for weeks that the IMF and the EU were split over how, and how quickly, to bring Greece's debt into line "burst into the open". But members of the press pack were still stunned to see the argument vented in public: So what can we look forward to today? Negotiations will continue in Brussels, where all 27 finance ministers from the EU are meeting. We'll be tracking all the action from there, and reaction to last night's deal. We also have UK inflation data released this morning, a Greek debt auction (crucial if it is to repay the €5bn loan that matures later this week), and the visit of David Cameron to Rome to meet Mario Monti. Should be lively....
fields.headline: Eurozone crisis as it happened: Greece gets more time as IMF and EU clash
fields.trailText: Further uncertainty for the eurozone as final decision on whether to hand Greece its next aid tranche is delayed for a week

webTitle: Banknote printer De La Rue drops 7% on order delays

fields.standfirst: Company says still expects to receive contracts in time for next year's figures
fields.body:
Banknote printer De La Rue has disappointed the market with news of delays in a number of contracts.

The company's shares have dropped more than 7%, down 79p at 985p, after the news. It said:

A number of significant orders which had been expected and planned for production in the second half of the current financial year have continued to be delayed. It will now be too late for these orders to benefit the current financial year, and as a result the board expects the financial results for the group for 2012/13 will be similar to those for 2011/12.

It said it was confident the delayed orders will be received for shipment in 2013. It gave no further details of the delayed contracts, prompting City wags to suggest one of them might be an order to print Greek drachma. The company has never commented on persistent rumours it might be involved in a revival of the Greek currency if it leaves the eurozone.

All this overshadowed news that first half profits had climbed 5% to £33m, although competition had increased with other manufacturers increasing capacity. Analyst Chris Dyett at Investec cut his price target from £10 to 940p, saying:

We downgrade our 2013 estimated earnings per share by 23%, solely due to the impact of these delays. However, we leave our 2014 estimates unchanged as we expect the orders to be received in due course.

De La Rue would have been the biggest faller in the FTSE 250 if not for Finnish miner Talvivaara Mining Company, down 8.35p to 87.4p on continuing delays at restarting production at its nickel mine in the east of the country. The mine has been leaking water for more than a week.

Paper producer Mondi is down 18.5p at 637p on talk Barclays was placing 19.3m at between 634p and 640p.

webTitle: Vodafone takes big hit on Spanish and Italian operations

fields.standfirst: For the six months ending 30 September, Vodafone made a loss of £1.98bn, compared with a net profit of £6.68bn a year earlier
fields.body:
Mobile communications company Vodafone reported a six-month loss as it booked a big charge on its Spanish and Italian operations.

For the six months ending 30 September, Vodafone made a loss of £1.98bn, compared with a net profit of £6.68bn a year earlier.

Revenue fell 7% to £21.8bn largely because of adverse currency movements.

The company said on Tuesday the £5.9bn impairment charge for Spain and Italy reflected lower projected cash flows and increased discount rates.

Service revenues across southern Europe were down by 9.8% in the six months and the company said it was suffering from "margin erosion" in Italy, Greece and Portugal.

Vittorio Colao, the company's chief executive, said: "We have continued to make progress on our strategic priorities over the last six months, with good growth in data and emerging markets in particular. In the short term, however, our results reflect tougher market conditions, mainly in southern Europe."

Richard Hunter, head of equities at Hargreaves Lansdown Stockbrokers, said: "The wider market has held concerns over southern Europe for some time now, and these numbers from Vodafone are uncomfortable proof that the financial fears are well-founded."

Vodafone shares fell 3.5% in early trading, to 161p.

webTitle: Gas prices: FSA examines whistleblower's claims of 'Libor-like' manipulation

fields.bodyText: UPDATE: on 7 November 2013 Ofgem and FCA concluded their investigation and found that there had been no market manipulation: http://www.fca.org.uk/news/statements/statement-gas-market-manipulation The City watchdog, the Financial Services Authority, is investigating claims by a whistleblower that Britain's £300bn wholesale gas market has been "regularly" manipulated by some of the big power companies, exploiting weaknesses that echo the recent Libor scandal. Separately, the energy regulator Ofgem has been warned by a company responsible for setting so-called benchmark prices, ICIS Heren, that it had seen evidence of suspect trading on 28 September, a key date as it marks the end of the gas financial year and can have an important influence on future prices. The whistleblower, who worked for ICIS Heren, raised the alarm after identifying what he believed to be attempts to distort the prices reported by the company. These benchmark prices are critically important because many wholesale gas contracts are based on them and small changes in the price can cost or save companies millions. The revelations come at a highly charged time for Britain's energy sector, with many of the big six suppliers under public fire for alleged profiteering on household energy bills and mis-selling on the doorstep. The energy secretary, Ed Davey, said : "I am extremely concerned about these allegations and will be keeping in close touch with the regulators while they get to the bottom of this." In a statement, the FSA said: "We can confirm that we have received information in relation to the physical gas market. We take market misconduct seriously and will be analysing the material." Ofgem said it had been given material "relating to trading in the gas market and is looking into the issue". The energy regulator said it had limited powers in this area but would "consider carefully any evidence of market abuse brought to our attention as well as scope for action under all our other powers". The City and energy regulators are keenly aware of the growing political concern that high energy prices, which are linked to wholesale values, can increase fuel poverty and undermine economic growth. , he Green MP Caroline Lucas said: "If these revelations stand up to analysis by the FSA and Ofgem, then this is corruption on a massive scale and a shameful case of corporates coming together to exploit a public utility." The market abuse concerns were initially raised by Seth Freedman, a former City trader who worked as a price reporter at ICIS Heren for nine months. He told the Guardian he believed problems he spotted in a frenzied half-hour of trading on 28 September were more widespread. "Traders have made clear to me that manipulation of gas prices is taking place on a regular basis. "They name big companies among those they accuse of trying to rig prices and reap profits. Market participants claim the fixing of prices is an open secret," he said. He also claimed that: • The big six companies are among those whose names are quoted by traders as being involved in attempts to raise or depress wholesale gas prices. • The key benchmark indices produced by at least one price reporting agency (PRA) and used increasingly in massive UK supply contracts are unreliable, and undermined by poorly-trained staff and over-cosy relationships between traders and price reporters. • Traders regularly put price reporters under pressure to change prices they disagree with. • Price reporters struggle to set accurate benchmarks because they lack detailed information about trading in the opaque so-called "over-the-counter" market and are dependent on what traders tell them about market activity. The disturbing issues raised by the traders he spoke to daily in his job at ICIS led Freedman to tape conversations about the 28 September price gyrations, which he has handed over to the FSA. In one, a trader from one power firm says: "There's a feeling among some people that somebody's taking the piss a bit on the day-ahead index. Between us I think [Company X] got in a bit of trouble for that about six months ago." It has not been possible to establish if any company was censured. Another trader told Freedman, who has previously been a freelance contributor to the Guardian, in an instant messaging exchange: "There are a few shops that continually try to distort closes from what I see … some of the range of quotes I hear sometimes are criminal." When Freedman flagged up a series of suspiciously low trades that he believed were designed to depress ICIS's "day-ahead" price on 28 September, a senior ICIS manager acknowledged they appeared to be an attempt to manipulate the price but said "actually we did a bad job investigating it". ICIS Heren did notify Ofgem about the suspicious trades. But, in another recorded conversation, the manager said there was "no official thing to do" when PRAs saw what they believed to be evidence of price manipulation. The whistleblower's information, handed over to the FSA, shows that on 28 September the price at which so-called day-ahead gas contracts were being bought and sold dropped sharply at precisely the time – 4.30pm – at which ICIS Heren attempts to take the pulse of the market. One explanation for this could be that traders were deliberately dealing below the prevailing price in order to drag the benchmark down, perhaps because they stood to gain more from other contracts linked to this benchmark. webTitle: House buyer inquiries leap in runup to Christmas

fields.standfirst: RICS says its members reported bounce in October, with 18% more respondents reporting rises than falls
fields.body:
The UK housing market is picking up as potential buyers scope the market before Christmas and more vendors put properties up for sale.

The Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS) said its members reported a bounce in new buyer inquiries in October, with 18% more respondents reporting rises than falls, up from just 5% the previous month.

Ian Perry, RICS housing spokesman, said: "The number of potential buyers going out and viewing property saw a welcome boost last month. It seems that with Christmas around the corner, those who are in a position to buy decided to get out there and see what is available."

On the supply side, RICS said the number of homes coming on to the market also rose – at the fastest rate since April 2011. Last month, 12% more respondents said there was a rise in vendors placing their properties on the market rather than a fall, up from 5% in September.

The organisation stressed that these improvements were still from a very low base. Perry said: "Overall activity is still very low in most parts of the country and what the market desperately needs is for this to translate into actual sales."

He said the NewBuy scheme – which allows house buyers to secure a 95% mortgage on new homes – needs time "to bed in and take effect". Access to affordable mortgages is still very difficult for many first-time buyers, he added.

But the Council of Mortgage Lenders said lending for house purchases dropped by almost 18% in September. Mortgage advances were up by 13% in the third quarter, but were little changed from the third quarter of 2011.

Howard Archer of IHS Global Insight said housing market activity remains very low compared to long-term norms and suggested house prices could well drift lower over the winter. "Certainly, any significant turnaround in house prices still looks some way off despite the economy seeing a better-than-expected rebound in GDP growth in the third quarter," he said.
